Yes it is.

Tab title updates look good now if I start it up with `./gradlew console`, however, if I run the console by doing the following:

```
./gradlew installGroovy
./target/install/bin/groovyConsole
```

I get this when viewing the `ASMifier` tab

```
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: groovyjarjarasm/asm/util/ASMifier
	at groovy.inspect.swingui.AstBrowser$_run_closure5$_closure40$_closure49.doCall(AstBrowser.groovy:296)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
	at org.codehaus.groovy.reflection.CachedMethod.invoke(CachedMethod.java:93)
```

@jwagenleitner @paulk-asert @blackdrag 
ping :)

+1 with some potential caveats as per below.

I'd certainly be happy to add the proposed code with a Class.forName check for a class in the asm-util jar and enable the tab if the class was found. For those of us that need it, it would certainly be easy enough for us to add the jar (and we could add some gradle smarts to make it even easier for us to invoke). We would want to avoid the class not found errors in any case. The feature certainly better aligns the groovyConsole with the IDEA ASM plugin in terms of functionality.

As to how/if the asm util jar gets bundled it is less clear to me the best way. I am just not sure the functionality has wide enough appeal to warrant jarjar embedding it within the groovyAll jar for instance. Perhaps that would be the most seamless way but perhaps excluding it from jarjar embedding and just bundling the lib jar within the zip might be a better approach?

As the creator of the PR it's easiest for you to close. But if you can't, let us know and we can force it closed as a side-effect of a commit containing a particular message - it's a standard Apache process.

@paulk-asert 
I've modified the PR as your suggestion. 
Please review it again. Thanks :)

*P.S. we can add asm-all jar file(http://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.ow2.asm/asm-all/6.0_ALPHA) to <GROOVY_HOME>/lib to show the ASMifier tab.*

Thanks Daniel, actually I just went and double checked what classes you'd be using out of the util jar and the ones we already bring out. It is only one extra class that we need. So, I think let's scrap my last suggestion (i.e. exclude the fcf550fa5 commit from the PR). Apologies for the extra work. And add this instead of your previous change to assemble.gradle:
```
--- gradle/assemble.gradle	(revision 93f703f53b01a0b0205d8efa364c3efb97758d31)
+++ gradle/assemble.gradle	(revision )
@@ -191,7 +191,7 @@
                         }
 
                         zipfileset(src: configurations.runtime.files.find { file -> file.name.startsWith('asm-util') },
-                                includes: 'org/objectweb/asm/util/Printer.class,org/objectweb/asm/util/Textifier.class,org/objectweb/asm/util/Trace*')
+                                includes: 'org/objectweb/asm/util/Printer.class,org/objectweb/asm/util/Textifier.class,org/objectweb/asm/util/ASMifier.class,org/objectweb/asm/util/Trace*')
                     }
                     rule pattern: 'antlr.**', result: 'groovyjarjarantlr.@1'
                     rule pattern: 'org.objectweb.**', result: 'groovyjarjarasm.@1'
```

Finally, do we have a Jira issue for this change? It would be good to have that for tracking purposes.

The rationale behind not attempting to actually get the charset (if available) from the URLConnection is because it hasn't been an issue to date.  So rather than introduce the complexity of parsing the `Content-Type` header it seems reasonable to defer until someone actually reports an issue.  The original issue that introduced the code [GROOVY-3934](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-3934) was not an issue about charset.
Travis is failing on the JDK8 build which I think is unrelated to this PR and seems to have started recently when the gradle version was bumped to 3.3.  Tests pass locally for me.
OK. I'll refine the PR later. Thank you, @paulk-asert  :)

I believe ages ago windows "globbing" worked to some degree. If you did:
```groovy -e "println args" *.groovy```
then windows would replace *.groovy with all the groovy filenames and pass all of them to your script (which in this case would just print out the names as a list).

This saved you having to worry about doing the expansion yourself - which at the time wasn't particularly easy outside of `ant`. I think that capability broke a long time ago and now only the first file found is returned or the error `The syntax of the command is incorrect` is returned if no matching file is found. I believe adding the `/F` will pass through the asterisk. This is a breaking change but in reality is probably what we want to do. We just need to document it and have some tests around it.

Similar suggestions have been made before but we haven't applied them because we never got the tests and doco in place. It would be great if you think you have time to flesh out either or both of those things but otherwise we'll add it to the long todo list.

The -D handling is also known about - our general strategy is that we want to reduce any processing happening in the bat file and have more handled in Groovy - but again we want some tests in place before making drastic changes.

We also need to get CI agents running windows that will then test any created tests - but that is a separate activity. If you do think you have time to do any additional work, I am happy to provide assistance.
I did a bit more testing and couldn't break it so far. I'll merge shortly.

On Sat, Apr 22, 2017 at 6:24 AM, Dmitry <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @paulk-asert <https://github.com/paulk-asert> Cool. About my previous
> comment. I've rechecked that case when a class doesn't hide static methods
> on the implemented interface and we try to call those methods on the class
> (not on the interface). In this situation Java just doesn't compile:
>
> interface Foo {
>   static void foo() {
>     System.out.println("static void foo() called");
>   }
> }
> class Bar implements Foo { }
> public class FooBarTest {
>     public static void main(String[] args) {
>         Bar.foo();
>     }
> }
>
> $ javac FooBarTest.java
> FooBarTest.java:3: error: cannot find symbol
>         Bar.foo();
>            ^
>   symbol:   method foo()
>   location: class Bar
> 1 error
>
> But Groovy does compile, both dynamic and @CompileStatic. So I was wrong
> about @CompileStatic point and here is a couple of questions:
>
>    1. Shouldn't @CompileStatic behave like Java in this case?
>    2. Should we fix this? I could investigate how it can be done
>
> Just in case, here is a snippet from *JLS8*:
> *8.4.8 Inheritance, Overriding, and Hiding*
> A class C inherits from its direct superclass all concrete methods m (both
> *static* and instance) of the superclass for which all of the following
> are true:
> ...
> A class does not inherit *static* methods from its superinterfaces.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/groovy/pull/521#issuecomment-296297124>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AARF0MUAYwoMlnaO_pSKltlhcieByG2lks5ryRBqgaJpZM4M2Qhm>
> .
>

Thanks for the reply Paul.  I see the point about the formatting and not wanting to make it part of the regular `MethodNode` api, so the utility classes are probably the best approach in this case.

I believe the following scenario accurately describes the race condition that causes the problem:

1. T1 in endScope calls `atomicCategoryUsageCounter.decrementAndGet()` and receives `0`
2. T2 in newScope calls `atomicCategoryUsageCounter.incrementAndGet()` and receives `1`
3. T2 assigns `categoriesInUse` a value of `1`
4. T1 assigns `categoriesInUse` a value of `0`
5. Callsite called from T2 calls `hasCategoryInCurrentThread` and return is `false`

Another way to fix would be to remove the int counter and just use the existing AtomicInteger. However, my hunch is that the int counter was retained because `hasCategoryInCurrentThread()` is probably called frequently so there might have been some performance concern over requiring a method call and a volatile read that the AtomicInteger would incur in order to implement the quick exit check for that method (`if (categoriesInUse == 0) return false`).

There is also a race between scopes in calls to `DefaultMetaClassInfo.setCategoryUsed`, so I think it would also be good to add those calls to the synchronized blocks if they are added.
Good suggestion - merged - thanks!
merged, thanks!
Thanks!

An example to show contentEncoding vs contentType

```groovy
url = 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jwagenleitner/groovy/a0e3335ab1d46fbe7ca7a0391fdf864c12d15f01/src/test/groovy/util/GroovyScriptEngineReloadingTest.groovy'

uc = new URL(url).openConnection()
uc.requestMethod = 'GET'

assert uc.contentEncoding == null
assert uc.contentType.toLowerCase().contains('utf-8')

uc = new URL(url).openConnection()
uc.requestMethod = 'GET'
uc.setRequestProperty('accept-encoding', 'gzip')

assert uc.contentEncoding == 'gzip'
assert uc.contentType.toLowerCase().contains('utf-8')
```
@blackdrag @paulk-asert if either of you have a chance I would be curious to know your opinion about this proposed change/fix.
